original_data.question: A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of several weeks of intense itching, particularly localized around his anus. Of note, the patient denies any recent travel, sexual contacts, fever, dysuria, or diarrhea. His temperature is 98.1°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 65/min, and respirations are 12/min. On exam, the patient demonstrates severe excoriations in his perianal region with slight erythema over the areas that are torn. He does not have any other dermatologic findings. The scotch tape test is positive. The patient has a previous documented allergy to albendazole. Which of the following is an alternative medication that can be used?

model_response:
The patient has pinworms (Enterobius vermicularis). The most common symptom is pruritus, which is often worse at night. The diagnosis is made by identifying eggs or adult worms in stool samples. Adult worms may be identified on the perianal skin using the scotch tape test. Pinworms are treated with albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate. Albendazole and mebendazole are contraindicated in patients with a history of neurocysticercosis. Pyrantel pamoate is the drug of choice for this patient because he is allergic to albendazole and mebendazole. Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication. Ivermectin is used to treat onchocerciasis, strongyloidiasis, and pediculosis. Praziquantel is used to treat schistosomiasis.

###Answer: OPTION D IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.

Care which provides integrated, accessible health care services by clinicians who are accountable for addressing a large majority of personal health care needs, developing a sustained partnership with patients, and practicing in the context of family and community. (JAMA 1995;273(3):192)
Any period of seven consecutive days.
The degree or magnitude of strength, energy, or feeling.
An intense itching sensation that produces the urge to rub or scratch the skin to obtain relief.
Being confined or restricted to a particular location. [HPO:probinson]
The lower opening of the digestive tract, lying in the cleft between the buttocks, through which fecal matter is extruded.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
MOVEMENT across different GEOGRAPHIC LOCATIONS.
Sexual interaction between individuals.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
Painful URINATION. It is often associated with infections of the lower URINARY TRACT.

An increased liquidity or decreased consistency of FECES, such as running stool. Fecal consistency is related to the ratio of water-holding capacity of insoluble solids to total water, rather than the amount of water present. Diarrhea is not hyperdefecation or increased fecal weight.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
An appraisal or evaluation of a patient's condition by a clinician that is based on a physical exam, medical history, and the patient's account of symptoms.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Self-inflicted tearing or wearing off of skin.
The skin area around the anus.
Redness of the skin produced by congestion of the capillaries. This condition may result from a variety of disease processes.
Torn, ragged, mangled wounds.
Having to do with the skin.
Involving advantage or good.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Furnished with or supported by documents and documentation.
A benzimidazole broad-spectrum anthelmintic structurally related to MEBENDAZOLE that is effective against many diseases. (From Martindale, The Extra Pharmacopoeia, 30th ed, p38)
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
